title: How to Handle Sunburn

content: An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure, and this is especially true with sunburns! When it comes to protecting your skin from the sun's rays, prevention is always better than treating it after the fact. But we’re human, and sometimes sunburns do happen. Yes, even I have had this happen. Usually, it’s due to forgetting to rub in our sunscreen over an area of skin or forgetting to reapply.
No matter the reason, here are some tips to help you treat sunburn if it does happen.
bullets: Don’t panic! If you feel your skin starting to hurt, turn red, or become swollen, those are signs you could be developing a sunburn. Most importantly, get out of the sun and seek shade immediately.
Cool off the skin by taking a cool shower or applying cool compresses to any areas of skin that are particularly hot or burning. This helps calm down inflammation, and it feels so good!

Apply a moisturizer to help lock in moisture as the sunburn heals. Avoid petrolatum-based products as they can occlude the skin and keep you too hot and uncomfortable. Instead, stick to a thick cream-based moisturizer. This is especially helpful as the skin starts to peel.

Take a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory product like aspirin, ibuprofen, or naproxen to help with any pain or burning you may feel. This helps calm down the inflammatory response that happens when the skin is sunburnt.

Be sure to stay hydrated with plenty of water or a sports drink containing electrolytes, especially as the skin peels. As we lose our skin barrier during a sunburn, we also lose hydration, so replenishing this is key.

content: Fortunately, most sunburns will usually heal without additional medical intervention within a week or so.
However, if your skin is not healing as expected, here are some signs where you should seek medical attention:
With enough sun exposure, ANYONE, no matter what skin type, can get a sunburn. No one is immune from sunburns. It just happens faster for people with lighter skin tones.

The best way to treat a sunburn is to avoid them entirely, but if you do get one, be sure to follow the tips above and prevent future sunburns by wearing SPF 30+ broad-spectrum sunscreen and sun-protective clothing. Your future skin will thank you!
bullets: You develop large blisters, especially covering a significant portion of your skin. Try to refrain from popping these blisters or removing the blister roof.
Seek treatment if you start to develop a fever, chills, or confusion.
If you have any concern for an infection in an area of skin breakdown, seek medical attention immediately.
